awd_abstract_narration:
This project at the University of Montana (UM) is improving undergraduate and graduate mathematics education by providing a learning environment that gives students the financial means, professional guidance, and community support they need to pursue degrees in the mathematical sciences. In addition the project seeks to develop a diverse student body whose composition reflects that of the state of Montana. Many students at UM are first-generation college students; many more face financial challenges. Thus, the largest part of the budget provides scholarships; however, scholarships are not enough so the project is creating pathways to draw students from all segments of the population into the mathematical disciplines and strengthen existing support structures so that, once on campus, these students can thrive and go on to challenging careers in technical areas of national need.

Because Native Americans form the largest minority group in the state, the project draws this population into the discipline by partnering with seven tribal community colleges on the reservation and three public community colleges in Montana. The project is extending the Missoula Math Circle to rural communities through video conferencing. The project provides two-year scholarships for talented, financially-needy undergraduate students; and provides fellowships for graduate mathematics majors who demonstrate financial need. Research opportunities, professional development, extensive mentoring, and peer and faculty mentoring are central to all levels of the program.  Since the mathematical sciences are foundational to all technical disciplines, improved access to high-quality mathematics programs holds promise to improve the learning and research environments in other STEM fields, as the pool of students with excellent quantitative ability becomes larger and more diverse at all levels.

por.por_cntn:
The project?s primary goal is to improve undergraduate and graduate mathematics education by providing a learning environment that gives promising students the financial means, mentoring, high expectations and community support they need to pursue and excel in their degrees in the mathematical sciences. A secondary goal is to develop a diverse student body whose composition reflects that of Montana.

This project at the University of Montana offers up to $10,000 per student per year for up to 4 years to talented, high achieving and low-income students majoring in mathematics. A suite of support is provided: multi-tier, cohort mentoring program, tutoring, research experience, research conference, and social interactions and community building.

Over the project period 35 students (15 undergraduates and 20 graduates) received scholarships. The demographics of the recipients are: 23% Latinx, 17.1% Native American, 5.7% Asian, 3% Black and 63% female. Twenty-one students have graduated (11 bachelors, 9 M.A. and 1 Ph.D. degrees), 9 are still enrolled in the program of study, one student transferred to another institution, and four left the program. Among the 21 students who successfully graduated 16 (76.2%) are female, which is significantly higher than the data at national level - in 2014, women received 41.7%  of bachelor's degrees in math/statistics, 42.8% of master's degrees, and 28.9% of PhD degrees (Retrieved on 8/31/2022 from NSF Digest Website: https://www.nsf.gov/statistics/2017/nsf17310/digest/fod-women/mathematics-and-statistics.cfm)

Increasing diversity in the mathematical sciences is important to society because it brings educational opportunities to communities that have to this point been left out of some of the major advances of our day. The modern workforce is strongest when it includes participation from all sectors of the society. Once students from the project graduate and enter the work force, in academia or industry, in addition to their contributions to the field, they serve as positive role models to help draw other such students into the mathematical sciences.

The project team has shared the lessons learned through this grant by recruiting for students at national conferences, presenting at a national mentoring conference, publishing an article, and continuous visitations to and communications with the tribal communities in Montana. Below is the abstract of the published article and its reference:

Abstract

Women and minority groups are underrepresented in the field of mathematics. Mentoring has been shown to have a positive effect on their retention that may offset the challenges associated with navigating traditional and historically male-dominated fields. A multi-tier, cohort mentoring program that contains a mentored research component has been implemented at the University of Montana since 2014. This article details the program results, demonstrating both the successes and challenges of the mentoring program.

McKinnie, K., McNulty, J., & Wu, K., (2019). Increasing the diversity of mathematicians of Montana through mentoring. In Proceedings of the 12th Annual Mentoring Conference, Towards the Science of Mentoring, the Mentoring Institute at UNM, Albuquerque, NM.
